questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after having a seizure. He has a 1-week history of headaches, blurry vision in his right eye, and muscle pain in his arms and neck. He has no history of a seizure disorder, and his vision was normal until the onset of symptoms. He has a history of migraine headaches that occur on a monthly basis and are relieved with ibuprofen. He immigrated from Ecuador 6 years ago and often returns to visit his family. He appears confused. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows subretinal cysts. Results of laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, and glucose levels, are within the reference ranges. An MRI of the brain shows multiple small ring-enhancing lesions in the parenchyma. HIV antibody test is negative. A lumbar puncture is performed; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows numerous eosinophils and a protein concentration of 53 mg/dL. Ingestion of which of the following is the most likely direct cause of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is tricky. When you chose this answer option, you likely considered how Taenia solium is transmitted since it is indeed the pathogen responsible for both cysticercosis and intestinal taeniasis. While both conditions are caused by the same pathogen, the life cycle stage (e.g., eggs, larvae, cysts) the pathogen is in when ingested determines which condition develops. Ingestion of larva from raw or undercooked pork most commonly results in the development of intestinal taeniasis. Infected pork meat contains cysticerci, which has an invaginated scolex. Once ingested, the scolex evaginates and attaches to the intestine walls using its hooks and suckers. The attached scolex produces proglottids and an adult tapeworm begins to develop. In contrast to intestinal taeniasis, cysticercosis develops after the ingestion of T. solium eggs, not larvae.

B) INCORRECT:

The ingestion of undercooked fish can result in the transmission of diphyllobothriasis. This condition is typically asymptomatic but can cause nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, diarrhea, and dizziness. Because Diphyllobothrium latum competes for vitamin B12 absorption in the small intestine, chronic infection can result in vitamin B12 deficiency and subsequent megaloblastic anemia. Although severe vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurologic manifestations such as peripheral nerve degeneration, it does not cause headache, blurry vision, or seizures. Moreover, diphyllobothriasis does not cause myalgia or subretinal cysts.

C) INCORRECT:

The ingestion of eggs from cat feces can result in the transmission of toxocariasis (from Toxocara cati) and toxoplasmosis. These conditions are typically asymptomatic but can result in ring-enhancing lesions on MRI and neurologic symptoms (e.g., headache, seizures) in rare cases. However, neither of these conditions causes myalgia or subretinal cysts. Moreover, central nervous system involvement of toxoplasmosis is usually only seen in patients who are immunocompromised; this patient has no history of immune deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

The ingestion of eggs from dog feces can result in the transmission of toxocariasis (from Toxocara canis) and echinococcosis. These conditions are typically asymptomatic. In rare cases, central nervous system involvement in toxocariasis can cause ring-enhancing lesions on MRI and neurologic symptoms (e.g., headache, seizures). When symptomatic, echinococcosis usually involves the liver and/or lungs and can cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, anorexia, weight loss, nausea, vomiting) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., cough, chest pain, dyspnea). Neither of these conditions causes myalgia or subretinal cysts.

E) CORRECT:

Cysticercosis, which is transmitted through the ingestion of Taenia solium eggs excreted in human feces, is endemic to several regions of the world, including Central and South America. The eggs hatch in the intestines, invade the intestinal wall, and disseminate hematogenously to different tissues, where they develop into larval cysts (cysticerci). Accumulation of cysticerci in muscle tissue results in myalgia. Ocular cysticercosis can manifest with subretinal cysts on ophthalmologic examination. Accumulation in the central nervous system and the resulting immune response can cause headache, symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, focal neurologic deficits, and seizures. Treatment of cysticercosis is complex and may include antiparasitic therapy (e.g., praziquantel, albendazole) and corticosteroids.

Patients with intestinal taeniasis can develop cysticercosis through autoinoculation (e.g., shedding of T. solium eggs in feces with subsequent fecal-oral transmission).
questions.hint: This patient most likely has cysticercosis, a condition that causes various symptoms based on where larval cysts accumulate. Multiple ring-enhancing lesions seen on MRI, neurologic symptoms (e.g., headache, seizures), and eosinophils in cerebrospinal fluid should raise concern for neurocysticercosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever and right leg pain and swelling for the past 3 days. Two weeks ago, he had a short episode of abdominal pain and diarrhea that resolved without treatment. He is an avid hunter and went hunting for wild boar with his father 3 weeks ago. He took some of the meat home for consumption. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Examination shows periorbital edema and conjunctival hemorrhage. Palpation of the right calf elicits tenderness. Range of motion of the right ankle is restricted by pain. A sample of which of the following is most likely to show the causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Trichinellosis is a helminth infection most commonly caused by ingesting the encysted larvae of Trichinella spiralis from undercooked meat (especially pork). The larvae invade the small bowel mucosa, where they develop into adult roundworms and may cause intestinal symptoms (intestinal phase). New larvae released by adult worms then migrate to striated muscles (muscle phase), where they encyst and cause myositis, often leading to severe muscle pain, as seen here. T. spiralis larvae are most likely to be seen in a sample of muscle tissue from the involved portion of this patient's right calf.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a striated muscle tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

Multiple encysted Trichinella spiralis larvae are visible throughout the sample. Most of the parasites are shown in cross-section (green overlay), some are visible in longitudinal section (green arrowhead).

B) INCORRECT:

A blood sample can be useful in the diagnosis of helminth infections, including trichinellosis. A typical (albeit unspecific) laboratory abnormality associated with helminth infections is eosinophilia. Trichinellosis also manifests with leukocytosis, elevated creatinine kinase, and specific antibodies, which are usually used to confirm the diagnosis. However, Trichinella spiralis larvae cannot be visualized in a blood sample.

C) INCORRECT:

A stool sample can be useful for direct identification of helminths such as Strongyloides stercoralis. Strongyloidiasis can manifest with fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. However, it is also associated with skin lesions (e.g., larva currens) and respiratory symptoms, neither of which are observed in this patient. Also, fever, severe leg pain and swelling, conjunctival hemorrhage, and periorbital edema are inconsistent with this diagnosis. Trichinella spiralis larvae cannot be visualized in a stool sample.

D) INCORRECT:

A lymph node tissue sample can be useful for direct identification of helminths such as Wuchereria bancrofti, a common cause of lymphatic filariasis. Lymphatic filariasis can manifest with fever (acute infection) and lower extremity swelling due to lymphedema (chronic infection). However, this condition manifests with painful lymphadenopathy rather than gastrointestinal symptoms, leg pain, periorbital edema, and conjunctival hemorrhage. Trichinella spiralis larvae cannot be visualized in a lymph node tissue sample.

E) INCORRECT:

A skin sample can be useful for direct identification of helminths like Enterobius vermicularis (tape test) and Onchocerca volvulus (skin snip test). Neither infection is associated with fever, severe leg pain and swelling, conjunctival hemorrhage, or periorbital edema. Trichinella spiralis larvae cannot be visualized in a skin sample.
questions.hint: An episode of abdominal pain and diarrhea followed by fever, leg pain and swelling, periorbital edema and conjunctival hemorrhage in a patient who consumed wild boar meat suggests trichinellosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Her mother says she has been having trouble sleeping for 3 weeks because of pruritus in her genital area. The girl has otherwise been feeling well. She is at the 45th percentile for height and 51st percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vulva and perianal region. There is no vaginal discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudohyphae on a potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mount of a perineal or vaginal swab is diagnostic of vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC). VVC may occur in pediatric patients, but it occurs more often in children who are still in diapers (candidal diaper dermatitis), which is not the case with this patient. VVC is characterized by white discharge and erythema of the intertriginous folds with “satellite” papules, neither of which are seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Perianal cellophane-tape examination (i.e., a tape test) is the diagnostic test for Enterobius vermicularis infection. At night, female worms migrate from the colon to the anal opening, where they deposit eggs, which cause perianal and vulvar irritation and pruritus. The test is conducted by applying a transparent piece of cellophane tape to the anal opening early in the morning; any ova of Enterobius vermicularis will then stick to the tape. By pressing the sticky side of the tape against a slide, anything picked up by the tape can be examined for the presence of eggs. If the tape test confirms pinworm infection, treatment of the entire household with albendazole or mebendazole is indicated to prevent reinfection.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the colon

A worm is visible in the colon (green overlay). The surrounding mucosa's surface and vascular pattern appear normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Wet mount microscopy is used to diagnose suspected trichomoniasis or bacterial vaginosis. While a burning sensation in the vulvovaginal area is a typical feature of trichomoniasis, a foul-smelling, yellow-green discharge is usually present as well. Bacterial vaginosis does not commonly cause vulvovaginal pruritus and instead presents with increased gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. The absence of vaginal discharge in this patient makes these infections unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Sexual abuse, and therefore STDs, are a concern in minors presenting with vulvovaginitis. However, in this patient, the absence of genital lesions or evidence of trauma make sexual abuse unlikely. Moreover, infections with Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhea are most often asymptomatic or manifest with symptoms of cervicitis (e.g., vaginal discharge or pain, bleeding on manipulation), urethritis (e.g., urethral discharge, dysuria, and urinary frequency), or pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g., fever, abdominal/pelvic pain). Nocturnal vulvar pruritus and erythema of the vulva and perianal region would not be expected.
Image Description:

Purulent discharge can be seen on this patient's vulva on external genital examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Stool microscopy can be used to diagnose gastrointestinal infections with protozoans (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica) or helminths (e.g., roundworms, tapeworms, and hookworms). In helminth infection, worm eggs (ova) can be detected in the stool. Enterobiasis, however, cannot be diagnosed reliably with stool microscopy because the ova of Enterobius vermicularis are almost never shed in feces. Instead, the gravid female worms migrate to the anal opening at night and deposit the ova there.
questions.hint: Anogenital pruritus (especially at night) in a toddler or preschooler is a classic symptom of enterobiasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 29 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of severe itching of the vulva and anal region for 2 weeks. During this time, she has had increasing abdominal pain and nausea associated with several episodes of vomiting and a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight loss. Last year, she had two episodes of vulvovaginal candidiasis that both subsided following treatment with oral fluconazole. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 29-week gestation. There are no signs of vulvar or perianal erythema, edema, or fissures. Microscopy of an adhesive tape that was applied to the perianal region shows multiple ova. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Praziquantel is not used for the treatment of enterobiasis. Praziquantel is effective against Schistosoma spp. and tapeworms such as Taenia spp. (e.g., intestinal taeniasis and neurocysticercosis) and Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), but these infections do not present with perianal pruritus.

B) INCORRECT:

Ivermectin is generally not used for the treatment of enterobiasis. Although it does have some efficacy against E. vermicularis, it is not effective enough to be considered for monotherapy. Ivermectin is the drug of choice for the treatment of infection with Strongyloides spp. or Onchocerca volvulus, but these infections do not manifest with perianal pruritus. Moreover, this medication is sometimes used as a second-line agent for treatment-refractory pediculosis pubis, which may manifest with pruritus in the genital and perianal regions. However, patients with pubic lice typically present with excoriations in the affected body area and lice or nits would be visible in the pubic hair rather than ova on a tape test. Finally, this drug should be avoided in this patient because the safety of administering ivermectin in pregnancy has not been established.

C) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is not used for the treatment of enterobiasis. This antibiotic is the first-line agent for the treatment of trichomoniasis, which manifests with vulvovaginal pruritus. However, ova on a tape test are not a typical finding. Instead, protozoa with multiple flagella would be visible on a wet mount of a vaginal smear. Moreover, patients with this condition usually have foul-smelling purulent vaginal discharge accompanied by a burning sensation, dyspareunia, dysuria, and an erythematous cervical mucosa with petechiae (strawberry cervix), none of which have been reported. Metronidazole is also indicated for treating bacterial vaginosis, which is most commonly asymptomatic and has a characteristic finding of clue cells on a wet mount.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is not used for the treatment of enterobiasis. This antifungal is the first-line agent for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis, which manifests with vaginal pruritus. However, ova on a tape test is not characteristic of this condition. Moreover, this drug should be avoided in this patient because the safety of administering fluconazole in pregnancy has not been established.

E) CORRECT:

Pyrantel pamoate is the first-line agent for the treatment of severe enterobiasis in pregnancy. In most cases, pinworm infection does not pose any risk to the fetus or the mother, and supportive treatment (i.e., strict hygiene measures) is preferred over pyrantel pamoate, which is considered a potential teratogen. This patient, however, shows symptoms of severe enterobiasis (i.e., nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, weight loss), which may compromise the pregnancy. In addition, she is already in the third trimester, by which time the risks to the fetus associated with pharmacological treatment are likely reduced. Bendazoles (e.g., albendazole, mebendazole) are another drug class commonly recommended for the treatment of pinworm infection; although these agents can be used after the first trimester, there is conflicting evidence regarding teratogenicity. If treatment is indicated, all household contacts should be treated simultaneously, because pinworm infections are highly contagious and reinfections are common.
questions.hint: Anogenital pruritus in combination with detection of ova in a tape test is consistent with enterobiasis. The presence of symptoms of intestinal infestation (abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting) indicates a high worm burden.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe muscle pain and swelling of his eyelids for 3 days. He has also had fever and chills during this period. For the last 2 days, he has had severe pain in his mouth while chewing. He had an episode of diarrhea a month ago for which he did not seek medical care. He has no history of serious illness. His sister has dermatomyositis. He returned from a hunting trip to eastern Europe 6 weeks ago. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema and severe generalized muscle tenderness. There are splinter hemorrhages on both hands. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,500/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils
60%


 Eosinophils

18%


 Lymphocytes
20%


 Monocytes
2%


Serum



 Glucose
100 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
100 U/L


 Creatine kinase
765 U/L


Urinalysis is within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Metronidazole at the onset of diarrhea

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clean drinking water is important for preventing many causes of food poisoning (e.g., Escherichia coli, Giardia lamblia, norovirus). However, this patient presents with symptoms suggestive of an infection with Trichinella spiralis, a parasite that is not transmitted through contaminated water.

B) CORRECT:

Trichinella spiralis causes trichinellosis and is typically acquired via ingestion of raw or undercooked meat from infected animals (e.g., pork), which contains encysted larvae. Following ingestion, larvae are released, invading the small bowel mucosa and then developing into adult worms. Adult worms migrate to muscles, where they encyst, causing the symptoms observed in this patient. This patient most likely consumed undercooked meat from animals hunted during his trip. Cooking meat to 71°C (160°F) kills any potential larvae in contaminated meat, preventing infection with Trichinella spiralis.

Early administration of anthelmintics, such as mebendazole and albendazole, may prevent potentially fatal complications such as arrhythmias, encephalitis, and respiratory failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone may be used for the treatment of a variety of autoimmune conditions including dermatomyositis, which may also manifest with myalgia, muscle weakness, increased levels of creatine kinase, and may occur in familial clusters. However, patients with dermatomyositis typically present with proximal muscle weakness affecting both sides of the body and many cutaneous manifestations, such as Gottron papules, a heliotrope rash, midfacial erythema, and shawl sign, none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

The consumption of pasteurized dairy products is important for preventing infection with, e.g., Listeria monocytogenes. L. monocytogenes causes listeriosis, which can also cause fever, diarrhea, and muscle aches. However, severe myositis and periorbital edema are not typical findings in listeriosis and this patient's eosinophilia indicates parasitosis, not a bacterial infection. Trichinella spiralis is not transmitted through the consumption of unpasteurized dairy products.

E) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is an antibiotic that is effective in treating parasites (e.g., Giardia lamblia) and anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Clostridioides difficile), which may also cause fever and diarrhea. However, this patient presents with many symptoms in addition to diarrhea, suggesting an infection with Trichinella spiralis (roundworms). Roundworms can be treated with anthelmintic agents such as albendazole and mebendazole. Antibiotics such as metronidazole are not effective.
questions.hint: This patient went on a hunting trip recently and now has fever, myalgia, periorbital edema, splinter hemorrhages, eosinophilia, and an increased serum creatine kinase concentration, all of which suggest an infection with Trichinella spiralis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of rash that began on his right ankle and gradually progressed up his calf. The rash is itchy and mildly painful. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin, glipizide, and enalapril. He returned from a trip to Nigeria around 5 weeks ago. He works on a fishing boat. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 150/86 mm Hg. Other than the rash on his calf, the examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis manifests with a rash on areas of the skin that have come into direct contact with an allergen (e.g., poison ivy). The rash manifests as intensely pruritic, erythematous vesicles and blisters that usually develop within 12–48 hours. Contact dermatitis is not migratory and therefore inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by a hookworm infection (e.g., Ancylostoma spp.), which is usually contracted by walking barefoot through soil contaminated with feces from an infected dog or cat. Infection initially manifests with a small red papule where the hookworm larva penetrates the skin. The subsequent serpiginous rash is an inflammatory reaction that follows the migratory path of the larva as it burrows through the epidermis. The larva secretes hyaluronidase and protease, which facilitate its movement. Zoonotic hookworms (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum) lack collagenase, which prevents them from penetrating the basement membrane and results in symptoms that are limited to the skin. Humans are an accidental intermediate host, and the infection is usually self-limiting, resolving on its own within 2 months. However, oral ivermectin or albendazole can be used to relieve symptoms and prevent secondary bacterial infection.

Human hookworms penetrate the skin and the basement membrane, migrating to the lungs through blood and lymphatic vessels. The larvae move via the bronchi and trachea to the larynx. Then, they are expectorated and swallowed back into the intestine, where they mature into adult worms.

C) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis manifests with erythematous, scaly plaques that spread centrifugally and develop central clearing. Inflammation causes scales, crust, papules, and vesicles. This patient's migratory serpentine rash is atypical for a tinea corporis infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Superficial thrombophlebitis manifests as a palpable cord and can have accompanying erythema, swelling, and pain. Since the lesions are typically neither itchy nor migratory, this diagnosis is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Swimmer's itch is an immune reaction to a water-borne cutaneous infection with Schistosoma. Affected patients develop itchy papules and blisters within hours of infection, which resolve within a week without intervention. This patient has a migratory rash that has lasted at least 3 weeks, making swimmer's itch an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: A pruritic, migrating, serpentine rash in a patient with recent travel to Africa is consistent with this condition.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive swelling of the left lower leg for 4 months. One year ago, he had an episode of intermittent fever and tender lymphadenopathy that occurred shortly after he returned from a trip to India and resolved spontaneously. Physical examination shows 4+ nonpitting edema of the left lower leg. His leukocyte count is 8,000/mm3 with 25% eosinophils. A blood smear obtained at night confirms the diagnosis. Treatment with diethylcarbamazine is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely route of transmission of the causal pathogen?

choices.text: Deposition of larvae into the skin by a female black fly
Penetration of the skin by cercariae from contaminated fresh water
Deposition of thread-like larvae into the skin by a female mosquito
Penetration of the skin by hookworms in feces
Ingestion of encysted larvae in undercooked pork

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deposition of larvae from the parasite Onchocerca volvulus into the skin by female black fly bites causes onchocerciasis. Early manifestations of this condition include a pruritic rash and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Onchocerciasis can cause genital elephantiasis due to lymphatic obstruction, but lower extremity lymphadenopathy is uncommon. In addition, this condition typically causes vision changes, which this patient does not have. Moreover, the treatment of choice for onchocerciasis is ivermectin, not diethylcarbamazine.

B) INCORRECT:

Schistosoma is transmitted by penetration of the skin by cercariae from contaminated freshwater. Early manifestations of schistosomiasis include a localized skin reaction at the point of entry and a febrile illness known as Katayama fever that develops 3–8 weeks after inoculation. Later manifestations include hepatosplenomegaly and ascites, but not lymphedema. In addition, Schistosoma is not prevalent in India. Moreover, the treatment of choice for schistosomiasis is praziquantel, not diethylcarbamazine.

C) CORRECT:

Infection with Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis after a mosquito vector introduces the filarial larvae into the skin during a blood meal. The larvae migrate through the bite wound and enter the lymphatic system, where they mature into adult worms. Infection can cause acute inflammation with symptoms of fever, chills, and tender lymphadenopathy that typically last for 1 week. Then, approximately 1 year after the initial infection, chronic inflammation and obstruction of the lymphatic vessels results in lymphedema, as seen in this patient with unilateral lower extremity swelling. First-line treatment for lymphatic filariasis is diethylcarbamazine.

D) INCORRECT:

Hookworms, such as Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus, are transmitted by penetration of the skin, usually by walking barefoot on soil contaminated with feces. After entering the skin, larvae migrate to the lungs via the bloodstream and lymphatic system. They are subsequently expectorated and swallowed and then colonize the intestinal tract. Symptoms of hookworm infection include a localized, pruritic rash at the site of penetration, pulmonary symptoms, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Though hookworm infection also causes eosinophilia, it does not cause lymphedema. In addition, the treatment of choice for hookworm infection is albendazole, mebendazole, or pyrantel pamoate, not diethylcarbamazine.

E) INCORRECT:

Ingestion of encysted larvae in undercooked pork is the mode of transmission of Trichinella spiralis, the parasite that causes trichinellosis. Once the cysts are ingested, larvae enter the small bowel and invade the mucosa, where they develop into adult worms. Early symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. Adult worms then migrate to muscles, where they encyst and cause myalgias. Though trichinellosis also causes eosinophilia, it does not cause lymphedema. The infection is typically self-limited, and analgesics are usually sufficient to treat symptoms. More severe infections can be treated with albendazole or mebendazole, not diethylcarbamazine.
questions.hint: This patient's history of tender lymphadenopathy after traveling to India, and his current presentation of unilateral leg swelling, are suspicious for lymphedema in the setting of lymphatic filariasis. The diagnosis is confirmed with a blood smear showing microfilariae, which classically circulate in the bloodstream during the night.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of intermittent loose stools and a 1.2-kg (2.6-lb) weight loss. She immigrated to the US from Uganda 6 weeks ago. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. The liver is firm and palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpable just below the left costal margin. Her leukocyte count is 12,800/mm3 (12% eosinophils). A photomicrograph of a stool sample is shown. Microscopic examination of a liver biopsy specimen shows granulomatous inflammation with periportal fibrosis. Exposure to which of the following is most likely to have played a role in the development of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

African sleeping sickness is caused by Trypanosoma brucei infection, a parasite transmitted by the tsetse fly. Early in the course of this disease, non-specific symptoms such as intermittent fever, headaches, lymphadenopathy, and arthralgias are seen (hemolymphatic phase). Weeks to months later, invasion of the central nervous system may lead to confusion, coordination problems, and sleeping disorders (neurological phase), none of which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Trichinella spiralis can be transmitted by ingestion of larvae in undercooked pork meat, causing trichinellosis. After ingestion of contaminated meat, cysts release larvae in the stomach, causing gastrointestinal symptoms including abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea (enteral phase). Adult worms then migrate to muscles, where they encyst, causing myalgia (parenteral phase). Taenia solium can also be transmitted by the ingestion of larvae (cysticerci) in contaminated raw pork meat. Hepatosplenic involvement, as seen in this patient, would not be expected with either of these parasites. Schistosomiasis is not associated with undercooked pork.

C) INCORRECT:

Ingestion of undercooked freshwater fish is the mode of transmission of Diphyllobothrium latum and Clonorchis sinensis. Both types of infection can lead to nonspecific gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Clonorchis sinensis infection can also affect the hepatobiliary tract and classically presents with cholelithiasis and cholangitis secondary to formation of brown pigment gallstones. However, the stool culture findings seen in this patient are not consistent with either of these pathogens and ingestion of freshwater fish is not associated with schistosomiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) and Echinococcus granulosus (hydatid tapeworm) are two parasites that can be acquired by ingestion of eggs from the feces of an infected dog. Echinococcosis is classically a condition of the lungs and liver and presents with single or multiple hepatic hydatid cysts, which may lead to liver enlargement. Symptoms of toxocariasis include weight loss and hepatomegaly. However, the stool culture findings seen in this patient are not consistent with either of these pathogens and exposure to dog feces is not associated with schistosomiasis.

E) CORRECT:

Freshwater snails in endemic regions serve as the intermediate host for schistosomiasis. Parasitic larvae (cercariae) initially penetrate the skin and enter the circulation to mature, and eventually produce eggs that migrate through the venous system and can spread to the lungs, spleen, liver, brain, and/or bladder (depending on the species of Schistosoma). Intestinal and hepatosplenic involvement is commonly seen with Schistosoma mansoni or Schistosoma japonicum infection, while bladder involvement only occurs with Schistosoma haematobium. Unlike the eggs of S. mansoni and S. japonicum, which have a lateral spine and are shed via human feces, the eggs of S. haematobium have a terminal spine and are excreted in urine. S. mansoni is endemic to Africa and South America, S. japonicum to East Asia, and S. haematobium to Africa and the Middle East.

Treatment of schistosomiasis includes praziquantel. Steroids can be added to the treatment to relieve hypersensitivity reactions.
Image Description:

An infected human, the definitive host of schistosomes, excretes schistosome eggs in urine or feces (yellow and brown arrow). The eggs hatch in water and release miracidia. These flat, ciliated larva penetrate specific freshwater snails, which then act as intermediate hosts. In the snail, the miracidia develop into sporocysts, which reproduce asexually to form cercaria. Cercaria are then released back in the water. When humans come in contact with contaminated water, cercaria can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation. As they lose their tail, the cercaria develop into schistosomula, which then mature into adult schistosomes in the venous system. At this point, a male and female adult worm mate and migrate to the veins of the target organs (liver, intestine, bladder). The female worm lies folded in the longitudinal cleft (schist) of the male worm and lays eggs, which causes inflammation of the organs. As a result of the inflammation, the eggs can penetrate the wall of the organ and enter the lumen of the intestine or bladder (depending on the species), and they are then eliminated in feces or urine.
questions.hint: This patient has features suggestive of intestinal and hepatosplenic schistosomiasis. An oval-shaped egg with a prominent lateral spine is consistent with Schistosoma mansoni infection.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a 6-month history of irritability. She has no history of significant illness and is up-to-date on her immunizations. She appears markedly lethargic. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows subconjunctival pallor. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.2 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. A photomicrograph of a wet stool mount is shown. Which of the following infectious agents is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hookworms (e.g., Necator americanus) are nematodes that are transmitted through hookworm larvae that penetrate the intact skin (usually the feet). While zoonotic hookworms (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense, Ancylostoma caninum) cannot penetrate the basement membrane, human hookworm (e.g., Necator americanus, Ancylostoma duodenale) larvae migrate to the intestines and cause chronic blood loss leading to iron deficiency anemia. Stool microscopy in this patient shows a transparent fertilized egg with 2–8 cell stages inside, which is consistent with Necator infection. Human hookworm infection can be treated with albendazole, mebendazole, or pyrantel pamoate.

B) INCORRECT:

Ascaris lumbricoides is a type of nematode contracted fecal-orally and results in ascariasis, which typically presents with respiratory symptoms (e.g., dry cough, blood-tinged sputum, wheezing) or gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g. abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting), neither of which are reported in this patient. Ascaris usually does not cause chronic GI blood loss. Moreover, Ascaris lumbricoides eggs have a knobby-coated round appearance unlike the specimen seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a wet mount of human feces

A yellowish-brown, round ovum with a knobby (mammillated) outer layer is visible.

This is the typical appearance of an Ascaris lumbricoides egg (the round shape indicates that it is fertilized).

C) INCORRECT:

Enterobius vermicularis is a type of nematode that causes pinworm infection, most commonly in children. It typically presents as nocturnal perianal pruritus, which is not reported in this patient. It is diagnosed by a tape test of the perianal region, which would show eggs that are ovoid and slightly flattened on one side. Infection with Enterobius vermicularis does not result in chronic gastrointestinal blood loss.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a specimen prepared by applying cellulose tape to the anal region of a patient (very high magnification)

Eight transparent, elongated oval eggs, which are flattened asymmetrically on one side can be seen.

D) INCORRECT:

Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) is a type of cestode whose eggs also resemble the one found here on photomicrograph. Long-standing infection can cause vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to a macrocytic megaloblastic anemia. However, this patient's MCV is low < 80 μm3, which is consistent with microcytic and not macrocytic anemia.
Image Description:

1. Diagnostic stage: Unembryonated eggs are shed in the feces of an infected definitive host (humans and most fish-eating mammals or birds).

2. The eggs embryonate in water, where they mature (18 to 20 days) and produce oncospheres that develop into coracidia.

3. The coracidia hatch from the eggs and are ingested by small crustaceans (first intermediate host).

4. The coracidia develop into procercoid larvae within the crustaceans.

5. Infective stage (mainly intermediate host): The infected crustacean is ingested by a small fish (second intermediate host), whereupon the procercoid larvae migrate into the deeper tissues and there develop into plerocercoid larvae. These small fish are rarely consumed raw by humans and, therefore, present a low risk of infection.

6. Infective stage (definitive host): Larger predatory fish ingest the smaller infected fish, which then serve as intermediate (paratenic) hosts. The pleroceroid larvae migrate to the muscle tissue of the paratenic host fish.

7. Infection of the definitive host occurs via ingestion of (undercooked) meat of the paratenic host fish.

8. The pleroceroid larvae develop into adult tapeworms in the small intestine, attaching to the intestinal mucosa via scolical bothria. Adult tapeworms produce over 3000 proglottids, which contain the unembryonated eggs. The proglottids release up to 1 million unembryonated eggs per day/tapeworm, which the definitive host passes in the feces.

E) INCORRECT:

Trichuris trichiura is a type of nematode contracted via the fecal-oral route that causes trichuriasis. Infection can cause iron deficiency anemia in children, as seen here. However, the eggs of Trichuris trichiura appear barrel-shaped with bipolar plugs, unlike the specimen in this case.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a wet stool mount (very high magnification)

Barrel-shaped, thick-walled eggs with bipolar hyaline protuberances are visible, which are characteristic of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

F) INCORRECT:

Taenia solium, a type of cestode that causes intestinal taeniasis and neurocysticercosis, is most commonly contracted by ingesting larvae from undercooked pork. This patient does not have abdominal pain or neurological symptoms, making infection with Taenia solium unlikely. Moreover, Taenia solium does not typically cause blood loss or iron deficiency anemia. Its eggs are round with a striated outer zone, unlike the specimen seen here.
Image Description:

The distinct head (scolex) of a pork tapeworm. Characteristic of Taenia solium are two rows of hooks, which permit attachment to the host's intestinal wall. In contrast to pork tapeworms, beef tapeworms do not have hooks.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (e.g., lethargy, irritability) and laboratory findings (microcytic anemia) are consistent with iron deficiency anemia. Stool microscopy shows the egg of a parasite.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of several months of recurrent abdominal pain and diarrhea. Six months ago, he traveled to Lake Superior for a fishing trip with his friends, during which they often ate their day's catch for dinner. Physical examination shows pallor. Laboratory studies show macrocytic anemia with eosinophilia. A peripheral blood smear shows hypochromic red blood cells with megaloblasts and hypersegmented neutrophils. A cestode infection is suspected and a drug is prescribed that kills cestodes by inducing uncontrollable muscle spasm in the parasite. The drug prescribed for this patient most likely acts by which of the following mechanisms of action?

choices.text: Increased calcium influx into the sarcoplasm
Increased sodium efflux from the sarcoplasm
Increased potassium efflux from the sarcoplasm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blockade of myosin binding sites on actin filaments would prevent the interaction of myosin and actin, which is essential for cross-bridge formation. Blocking myosin binding sites would inhibit muscle contraction, rather than causing muscle contraction or spasm.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is most likely treated with the antihelminthic medication praziquantel, which causes contracted muscle paralysis in parasites by increasing calcium influx into the sarcoplasm of the parasite. Calcium binds to troponin C and results in a conformational change that exposes myosin-binding sites on actin filaments. According to the sliding filament theory of muscle contraction, this enables actin and myosin to form cross-bridges. Contracted muscle paralysis of the parasites caused by treatment with praziquantel facilitates their destruction by the host immune system.
Image Description:

The crossbridge cycle describes the calcium-dependent interaction of actin and myosin during muscle contraction (myosin head = pink; actin = blue).

1.) Released state: the myosin binding site on the actin filament is blocked by tropomyosin → no interaction between myosin and actin. The myosin head is in a low-energy 45° position with ATP bound to it.

2.) Cocked state: ATP is hydrolyzed, yielding ADP and phosphate → cocking of myosin head (high-energy 90° position). The myosin binding site remains blocked.

3.) Crossbridge state: activation of muscle cell with influx of calcium. Binding of calcium to troponin → tropomyosin is displaced from myosin binding site on actin filament → myosin head binds to actin filament (crossbridge formation).

4.) Power stroke: release of the phosphate bound to the myosin head → power stroke of myosin head → myosin head moves along the actin filament. This action results in muscle contraction and/or tension, depending on the situation. Afterward, the myosin head returns to the low-energy 45° position.

5.) Detached state: release of ADP → binding and hydrolyzation of a new ATP molecule and subsequent release of the myosin head. If the calcium concentration remains high, the crossbridge cycle starts again. If the calcium concentration decreases, the myosin binding site is once again blocked by tropomyosin and the crossbridge cycle ends.

C) INCORRECT:

An increased sodium influx into the sarcoplasm (not an increased sodium efflux from the sarcoplasm) is generated when acetylcholine binds to ligand-gated receptors of the neuromuscular endplate. This induces an excitatory postsynaptic potential that causes opening of further voltage-dependent sodium channels, generating an action potential, which eventually leads to muscle contraction. Increased sodium efflux from the sarcoplasm does not cause muscle contraction or spasm.

D) INCORRECT:

Blockade of L-type calcium channels is the mechanism of action of calcium channel blockers, such as nifedipine and amlodipine. These medications block the flow of calcium into vascular smooth muscle cells, thereby producing a vasodilatory effect. Therefore, their effect on muscle tissue is opposite from that of the medication used in this patient. Moreover, these drugs are not used for the treatment of cestode infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Potassium efflux from the sarcoplasm is part of the physiological process of cell membrane repolarization. Increased potassium efflux from the sarcoplasm helps to restore the resting membrane potential in myocytes, which would lead to disruption of muscle contraction, rather than causing muscle contraction or spasm.

F) INCORRECT:

Binding of ATP, which is generated by phosphorylation of adenosine diphosphate (ADP), to myosin heads leads to detachment of myosin from actin filaments, which disrupts the cross-bridge cycle and ends muscle contraction. However, hydrolysis of myosin-bound ATP to ADP and Pi alters the myosin head conformation to a cocked state, which primes the myosin for cross-bridge formation with actin to generate muscle contraction.
questions.hint: This patient shows signs of chronic enteritis associated with megaloblastic anemia. A history of eating freshwater fish suggests a helminthic infection by Diphyllobothrium latum.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with hypertension is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. She has had recurrent headaches and dizziness in the last 3 months. One year ago, she had a diarrheal illness following a trip to Ecuador that resolved without treatment. She has not received any medical care in the last five years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Her temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F) and blood pressure is 159/77 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dysarthria and hyperreflexia. She is confused and oriented only to name and place. On a CT scan of the head with contrast, four brain lesions are seen; one of the lesions is shown. Which of the following would have been most likely to prevent this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Avoidance of food contaminated by the eggs of Taenia solium reduces the risk of neurocysticercosis, which is the most common parasitic disease of the nervous system and the most important cause of adult-onset seizures in Asia, Africa, Central and South America. Neurocysticercosis is a fecal-oral transmitted disease that results from ingestion of eggs of Taenia solium, which can be found in food and water contaminated by the feces of people with intestinal taeniasis. Several strategies have been described to prevent the infection, which include washing food prior to consumption, proper hand hygiene, and avoidance of raw pork meat, as well as adequate freezing and cooking of food to destroy the parasite.

Neurocysticercosis is characterized by seizures, increased intracranial pressure, and focal neurologic deficits. Depending on the stage of disease, multiple ring-enhancing, cystic, and eventually calcified lesions can be seen on brain CT scan, some of which may show a scolex.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against meningococcus is routinely recommended in adolescents 11–18 years old and high-risk groups to reduce the risk of infection with Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative diplococcus responsible for most of the cases of community-acquired meningitis in children and young adults. Although meningococcal meningitis can also cause neurological deficits as in this patient, other important signs such as neck stiffness and signs of infection (e.g., fever) are not present. In addition, meningococcal meningitis does not cause ring-enhancing lesions but instead presents with inflamed meninges on imaging. Therefore, vaccination would not have prevented this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Avoidance of cat feces reduces the risk of infection with Toxoplasma gondii, a ubiquitous intracellular parasite acquired by ingestion of oocytes from water, fruits, vegetables or contaminated meat. Cerebral toxoplasmosis can also cause neurological deficits and ring-enhancing lesions on brain CT scan. This diagnosis is very unlikely in an immunocompetent patient. Given the patient's gastrointestinal infection acquired in South America, another diagnosis is more likely. Therefore, avoidance of cat feces would not have prevented this patient's condition.

Echinococcus spp. can also be transmitted by ingestion of eggs shed in feline feces. However, the clinical manifestations of echinococcosis are mostly gastrointestinal and pulmonary rather than neurologic.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking cessation is the best strategy to reduce the risk of lung cancer, which is the most common cause of brain metastases. In a patient with a history of smoking and symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure, ring-enhancing lesions are concerning for metastatic lung cancer. However, brain metastasis manifests with vasogenic edema, which is not seen here, and this patient's history of a diarrheal illness following a trip to Ecuador a year ago makes another diagnosis more likely. Therefore, smoking cessation would not have prevented this patient's condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Mammography screening is routinely performed in women 40–74 years old with an average risk of breast cancer, the most common malignant disease in postmenopausal women. Although breast cancer has a high risk of metastasizing, most patients have a previous diagnosis of primary disease and < 5% present with brain involvement. Additionally, brain metastasis on CT scan appears as multiple, well-circumscribed lesions at the gray-white matter junction, and not as ring-enhancing, cystic lesions like those observed in this patient. Therefore, breast cancer screening would not have prevented this patient's condition.

F) INCORRECT:

Improved blood pressure control minimizes the chances of stroke in patients with elevated cardiovascular risk. Although this patient presents with a history of untreated hypertension, her blood pressure at the time of evaluation is not high enough to produce acute end-organ damage. Additionally, the morphologic features of the lesions on brain CT scan are not characteristic of ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke. Therefore, improving blood pressure would not have prevented this patient's condition.
questions.hint: This patient's combination of seizure, headache, dizziness, dysarthria, hyperreflexia, confusion, recent travel to South America, and ring-enhancing brain cysts on head CT scan indicates a diagnosis of neurocysticercosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 4-week history of irritability, diarrhea, and a 2.2-kg (5-lb) weight loss that was preceded by a dry cough. The family returned from a vacation to Indonesia 2 months ago. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness with no guarding or rebound and increased bowel sounds. Her leukocyte count is 9,200/mm3 with 20% eosinophils. A photomicrograph of a wet stool mount is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diethylcarbamazine is used for the treatment of Loa Loa filariasis and Wuchereria bancrofti. Loa Loa filariasis and Wuchereria bancrofti are both vector-borne nematodes commonly found in Africa. Loiasis can cause conjunctivitis (worm migrates across the conjunctiva) and subcutaneous swellings (Calabar swellings). Wuchereria bancrofti infects the lymphatic system, causing elephantiasis. Neither presents with intestinal or pulmonary symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is used to treat infection with certain protozoa (e.g., Giardia, Entamoeba) as well as anaerobes. Giardia lamblia and Entamoeba histolytica are fecal-orally transmitted protozoans that are most commonly found in the tropics and subtropics. Both present mainly with intestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain) but pulmonary symptoms would not be present. Stool microscopy would show trophozoites or cysts, rather than nematode eggs, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for several bacteria, including Chlamydia trachomatis, Borrelia burgdorferi, and Vibrio cholerae. Vibrio cholerae is fecal-orally transmitted, and can also manifest with watery (rice-water) diarrhea, frequently leading to severe dehydration. However, pulmonary symptoms would not occur and a stool sample culture would show gram-negative, flagellated, comma-shaped rods rather than nematode eggs, as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Infection with Ascaris lumbricoides is acquired fecal-orally by ingestion of Ascaris eggs in contaminated food. Once the eggs hatch, the larvae burrow through the intestinal wall and migrate to the lungs, causing pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dry cough, blood-tinged sputum, wheezing). Re-expectorated larvae then migrate back to the intestines and mature into adults, where they can cause abdominal symptoms, including nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort due to obstruction of the bowel, appendix, or biliary ducts by adult worms. First-line treatment of ascariasis consists of bendazoles (e.g., albendazole, mebendazole).
Image Description:

A type of soil-transmitted helminth; 15-cm long specimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Praziquantel is used in the treatment of most trematode infections (e.g., schistosomiasis) as well as certain cestode infections (e.g., Taenia solium, Diphyllobothrium latum). Both schistosomiasis and taeniasis can present with abdominal symptoms, and schistosomiasis can also present with pulmonary symptoms (pulmonary schistosomiasis). However, taenia eggs do not have the knobby appearance seen here and Schistosoma eggs are characterized by a lateral or terminal spine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urine concentrate (wet mount; 500× magnification)

An oval-shaped egg (green overlay) with a transparent shell (red outline), a small protrusion at one pole, and a sharp terminal spine (blue line) is pictured.

This is the characteristic microscopic appearance of a Schistosoma haematobium egg, which is excreted in the urine (or feces) of an infected host.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (dry cough, followed by diarrhea and abdominal pain), laboratory findings (eosinophilia), and history of recent travel to an endemic region are concerning for a nematode infection. Her stool sample shows a fertilized egg with a knobby appearance, confirming the diagnosis of Ascaris lumbricoides infection.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of itching of the vulva and anal region for the past 2 weeks. She has difficulty sleeping because of the itching. Physical examination shows excoriation marks around the vulva and perianal region. There is minor perianal erythema, but no edema or fissures. Microscopy of an adhesive tape applied to the perianal region shows multiple ova. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bendazoles (e.g., mebendazole, albendazole) bind to the tubulin subunit in helminths and inhibit microtubule polymerization. They are an appropriate treatment for pinworm infection, which is caused by Enterobius vermicularis. Alternatively, pyrantel pamoate can be used. Initial infection with pinworms is fecal-oral, but reinfection occurs via the digital-oral route due to pinworm eggs which cause nocturnal pruritus.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a specimen prepared by applying cellulose tape to the anal region of a patient (very high magnification)

Eight transparent, elongated oval eggs, which are flattened asymmetrically on one side can be seen.

B) INCORRECT:

Melarsoprol is used in the treatment of African trypanosomiasis, caused by Trypanosoma brucei, which manifests with recurrent fever, lymphadenopathy, somnolence, and coma. Perianal pruritus and a positive tape test, as seen here, are not typical for trypanosomiasis, and melarsoprol is generally not used for the treatment of enterobiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Diethylcarbamazine is used to treat lymphatic filariasis, which is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, and loiasis, which is caused by Loa loa. Lymphatic filariasis presents with fever, painful lymphadenopathy, and progressive swelling of the region drained by the obstructed lymphatics (often the lower extremities), potentially leading to elephantiasis. Loiasis is usually asymptomatic but may present with localized subcutaneous swellings and a visible migrating worm in the conjunctiva. Neither lymphatic filariasis nor loiasis manifests with perianal pruritus and a positive tape test, and diethylcarbamazine is generally not used for the treatment of enterobiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Nifurtimox is used to treat Chagas disease, caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, which manifests with nonspecific symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, anorexia) and, rarely, edema or more severe disease of the heart, gastrointestinal, and/or nervous system. However, it does not present with perianal pruritus and a positive tape test, as seen here, and nifurtimox is generally not used for the treatment of enterobiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ivermectin is the drug of choice for the treatment of infection with Strongyloides stercoralis or Onchocerca volvulus. Strongyloidiasis can present with pruritus, typically of the feet, where larvae enter the skin. However, perianal pruritus, as this patient has, is not common. Onchocerciasis can cause skin changes as well as ocular disorders and blindness. Neither condition is known for causing perianal pruritus and a positive tape test. Ivermectin is generally not used for the treatment of enterobiasis.

F) INCORRECT:

Praziquantel is effective against Schistosoma, Taeniasis, Clonorchis sinensis, and Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) infections. Intestinal schistosomiasis, taeniasis, and clonorchiasis, if symptomatic, all manifest with gastrointestinal symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Schistosomiasis may also cause gastrointestinal strictures or bleeding. Chronic infection with fish tapeworm can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency and anemia. However, none of these infections manifest with perianal pruritus and a positive tape test. Praziquantel is not used for the treatment of enterobiasis.
questions.hint: This patient has a positive tape test showing the presence of ova (i.e., the eggs of a worm). Her anal pruritus is therefore most likely caused by a pinworm infection (i.e., enterobiasis). Gravid female pinworms migrate to the rectum of infected individuals, usually at night, and deposit their ova nocturnally in the anogenital region, causing inflammation and itching.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of episodic abdominal pain and fullness. She works as a veterinary technician. Physical examination shows hepatomegaly. Abdominal ultrasound shows a 4-cm calcified cyst with several daughter cysts in the liver. She undergoes CT-guided percutaneous aspiration under general anesthesia. Several minutes into the procedure, one liver cyst spills, and the patient's oxygen saturation decreases from 97% to 68%. Her pulse is 136/min and blood pressure is 86/58 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Strongyloides stercoralis is a threadworm that penetrates the skin of hosts and migrates to the lungs, where it matures. Larvae then travel to the pharynx and are swallowed. Infection can manifest with cutaneous, respiratory, or intestinal symptoms. Hepatic involvement is uncommon and this condition does not cause the calcified, unilocular liver cysts seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Trichinella spiralis is a nematode that causes trichinosis, a condition that manifests with intestinal symptoms, splinter hemorrhages, retinal and conjunctival hemorrhages, periorbital edema, rash, and chemosis. Infection spreads through fecal-oral transmission and consumption of undercooked meat. Hepatic involvement is uncommon and this condition does not cause the calcified, unilocular liver cysts seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) infection occurs after ingestion of larvae through undercooked pork or contamination with human feces. It causes intestinal taeniasis, cysticercosis, and neurocysticercosis. Hepatic involvement is uncommon and this condition does not cause the calcified, unilocular liver cysts seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Schistosoma mansoni uses freshwater snails as intermediate hosts and infects humans via penetration of the skin. Infection manifests with a pruritic, maculopapular rash at the point of entry and a serum sickness-like disease. Chronic schistosomiasis can manifest with hepatic, splenic, pulmonary, and/or neurologic involvement. However, it does not typically cause calcified, unilocular liver cysts as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke) is a trematode transmitted by ingestion of undercooked fish. It causes infection and obstruction of the biliary tract and is associated with chronic inflammation and increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma. It does not typically cause calcified, unilocular liver cysts as seen in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Echinococcus granulosus is a tapeworm of which the definitive hosts are foxes, dogs, and cats. The intermediate hosts are sheep and rodents. Infection occurs through fecal-oral transmission of eggs. Hepatic echinococcosis typically causes malaise, nausea, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and an anechoic, well-defined, hepatic cyst (hydatid cyst) with or without daughter cysts and eggshell calcification on ultrasonography. Any invasive procedure (drainage or surgery) of hydatid cysts should be performed with the utmost care to prevent spillage of cyst contents, which can cause life-threatening anaphylactic shock and/or secondary seeding of infection.

Echinococcus granulosus, which causes cystic echinococcosis, typically presents with unilocular hydatid cysts, while Echinococcus multilocularis, the causal organism of alveolar echinococcosis, is characterized by formation of multiple cysts with infiltrative growth.
Image Description:

Transverse CT abdomen

A single hypodense septated cyst in the right lobe of the liver (red overlay) can be seen. The cyst is most likely due to Echinococcus granulosus.

L: liver; S: stomach; V: vertebra; A: aorta; K: kidney; Sp: spleen

G) INCORRECT:

Ascaris lumbricoides is a nematode that spreads via fecal-oral transmission. Larvae invade the intestines and then migrate from the portal circulation to the lungs, from which they are coughed up and swallowed. Infections manifest with respiratory and intestinal symptoms. Adult worms can migrate to the biliary tract and cause obstruction with cholestasis. However, it does not typically cause calcified, unilocular liver cysts as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This woman with previous exposure to animals has developed anaphylactic shock (tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, hypoxia) due to spillage of cyst contents into the bloodstream, which is a complication of the surgical management of a particular tapeworm infection.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his host parents for evaluation of a progressively pruritic rash over his shoulders and buttocks for the past 6 months. He recently came to the United States from Nigeria to attend a year of high school. He reports that it has been increasingly difficult for him to read the whiteboard during classes. Physical examination shows symmetrically distributed papules 4–8 mm in diameter, excoriation marks, and patchy hyperpigmentation over his shoulders, waist, and buttocks. There is nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy and several firm, nontender subcutaneous nodules along the right iliac crest. Six skin snip biopsies are taken from the pelvic girdle, buttocks, and thigh, and are then incubated in saline. After 24 hours, microscopic examination shows motile microfilariae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lymphatic filariasis, a tropical disease caused by the filarial worm Wuchereria bancrofti, can manifest with skin changes (e.g., hyperpigmentation), lymphadenopathy, and rarely ocular involvement, as seen here. However, filariasis initially presents with fever and painful (rather than painless) lymphadenopathy, followed by lymphedema due to chronic inflammation of the lymphatic vessels. Moreover, lymphatic filariasis is diagnosed by the detection of microfilaria in midnight blood samples, not skin biopsies.
Image Description:

Photograph of the legs of an adult male

Severe edema of the lower legs.

This is likely due to an infection with tropical roundworms (lymphatic filariasis).

B) CORRECT:

Onchocerciasis (river blindness) is caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus and is transmitted via the bite of the blackfly (Simulium spp.), the intermediate host that inoculates O. volvulus larvae into human skin. The larvae mature into adult filaria and become encapsulated within subcutaneous nodules (onchocercomas), which are typically located over bony prominences (e.g., iliac crest). The filaria produce thousands of microfilaria, which migrate through the skin, lymphatics, and blood to reach the lymph nodes, eyes, and deep organs. The inflammatory response to these microfilariae can cause ocular disease (e.g., keratitis, uveitis) as well as an intensely pruritic papular dermatitis with secondary skin changes due to itching (e.g., excoriations, hyperpigmentation). Onchocerciasis is diagnosed by the presence of microfilaria in skin snip biopsies and treated with ivermectin.

C) INCORRECT:

Trichuriasis, a tropical gastrointestinal disease caused by the whipworm Trichuris trichiura, would manifest with mucoid or bloody diarrhea, anemia, and, in the case of heavy infestation, rectal prolapse. Trichuriasis is not associated with the visual impairment, skin lesions, or lymphadenopathy seen in this patient, and it is diagnosed by stool examination for eggs.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a wet stool mount (very high magnification)

Barrel-shaped, thick-walled eggs with bipolar hyaline protuberances are visible, which are characteristic of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

D) INCORRECT:

Cysticercosis is caused by the ingestion of Taenia solium eggs. The clinical manifestations of cysticercosis depend on whether the cysticerci are localized to the brain parenchyma or to extra-parenchymal tissues. Intraparenchymal cysticercosis typically presents with seizures. Visual impairment and subcutaneous skin nodules can be seen in extra-parenchymal cysticercosis. However, cysticercosis is not typically associated with lymphadenopathy or a papular skin rash.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (FLAIR sequence)

A hyperintense nodule is visible along the margin of a rounded lesion (hole-with-dot sign) in the right frontal lobe that is isointense to CSF.

The fluid-filled lesion (cysticercus; green overlay) is a larval cyst of the pork tapeworm, with the scolex (red overlay) seen as the hyperintense nodule. The finding is consistent with neurocysticercosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM), a tropical infection caused by zoonotic hookworms (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense, Ancylostoma caninum), can manifest with a pruritic papular skin rash, as seen here. Ocular involvement has also been reported in a few cases of A. caninum infection. However, the rash in CLM usually occurs first on the feet and ankles (rather than the shoulders) because the hookworm larvae enter the skin at sites that have been in contact with contaminated soil. Moreover, CLM is not typically associated with skin hyperpigmentation, subcutaneous nodules, or lymphadenopathy.
Image Description:

Ankle of a patient with cutaneous larva migrans

Serpiginous marks (larval tracks) are visible here. However, in the case of a strong local inflammatory response, these marks may not be visible.

Serpiginous marks together with pruritus establish the diagnosis of cutaneous larva migrans.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a parasitic disease that is endemic to Nigeria and transmitted by the female blackfly.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a 2-week history of headaches is brought to the emergency department after she has a seizure. The seizure reportedly started with involuntary, rhythmic shaking of the left arm, progressed to involve the other limbs, and then resulted in a loss of consciousness. The patient is originally from Peru and lives with her sister, who recently immigrated to the United States.
The patient is afebrile with no meningeal signs. Neurologic examination shows a normal mental state but reveals a pronator drift on the left side.
A T1-weighted postcontrast image of a brain MRI is obtained (figure). Other cuts show three more lesions that appear similar to those shown here.
In addition to antiepileptic drug therapy, which one of the following treatments is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The imaging finding of multiple enhancing cystic lesions in a patient from Peru is highly suggestive of neurocysticercosis. Imaging after contrast administration can show simple intraparenchymal cysts (panel B, arrow) and sometimes a cystic lesion with a central area of enhancement (panel A, arrow), which is indicative of the scolex in the lesion.

Neurocysticercosis is caused by Taenia solium infection. Humans can acquire the disease either by eating undercooked meat containing the cysts (thereby becoming T. solium tapeworm carriers) or by ingesting the eggs via fecal-oral transmission. The parasite releases oncospheres into the host's digestive tract; these travel to end organs, including the brain, and become encysted. Brain cysts can become a focus for seizures.

The recommended treatment for neurocysticercosis depends on the number of viable parenchymal cysticerci. If there are only one or two viable lesions, monotherapy with albendazole is recommended. In patients with three or more viable parenchymal cysticerci (as in this case), treatment consists of combination therapy with albendazole and praziquantel. Regardless of the antimicrobial treatment regimen chosen, the patient should also receive antiinflammatory treatment with a glucocorticoid, such as dexamethasone, to reduce the likelihood of seizure recurrence. Of note, patients with calcified parenchymal cysticerci are not treated with antiparasitic or antiinflammatory drugs.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for parenchymal neurocysticercosis with more than two viable lesions is albendazole, praziquantel, and a glucocorticoid.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus encephalitis, which is unlikely in this patient given the absence of fever or meningeal signs.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone and vancomycin, the empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis, is not effective against T. solium.

D) INCORRECT:

The recommended treatment for neurocysticercosis depends on the number of viable parenchymal cysticerci. If there are only one or two viable lesions, monotherapy with albendazole is recommended. In patients with three or more viable parenchymal cysticerci (as in this case), treatment consists of combination therapy with albendazole and praziquantel. Regardless of the antimicrobial treatment regimen chosen, the patient should also receive antiinflammatory treatment with a glucocorticoid, such as dexamethasone, to reduce the likelihood of seizure recurrence.

E) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol are used to treat tuberculous meningitis, which typically manifests with multiple cranial-nerve abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department (ED) with a 3-day history of nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea that began suddenly on the last day of a weeklong cruise to the Galápagos Islands. He also reports lightheadedness, one syncopal episode earlier today, and diminished urine output. He reports no fevers, headache, stiff neck, or photophobia. The syncope, which occurred as he was attempting to stand up from a chair, was preceded by a feeling of lightheadedness and blurry vision. His father, who observed the episode, reports no involuntary movements but says that his son may have struck his head on the edge of the chair as he fainted. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He was originally born in India but is now a graduate student in California. He reports that other people on the cruise also had nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
He has a temperature of 37.8°C, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. Lying on the stretcher, he has a heart rate of 88 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 122/72 mm Hg; after he stands, his heart rate is 108 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. He has a slight bruise above the right ear. The rest of his physical examination — including abdominal examination, detailed neurologic examination, and fundoscopy — is normal.
An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm. Laboratory evaluation reveals a blood urea nitrogen level of 35 mg/dL (reference range, 10–20) and a serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL (0.8–1.3) but normal results for complete blood count, liver enzyme levels, and electrolyte levels.
Noncontrast head CT reveals multiple calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: MRI of the brain with contrast
Stool examination for ova and parasites

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radionuclide cisternography is appropriate when there is concern for intracranial hypotension, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak, or CSF flow abnormalities, which is not the case in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

In patients who have lived in an area that is endemic for cysticercosis (as in this case) or traveled to such an area, the presence of calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma on CT should raise suspicion for neurocysticercosis. Calcified lesions generally occur 5 to 30 years after exposure, and in this case, are not related to the patient’s recent trip to the Galápagos Islands.

Neurocysticercosis refers to infection of the central nervous system (CNS) by the larval stage of the pork tapeworm, Taenia solium, which is endemic in South America, Asia, and Africa. This organism is transmitted among humans primarily via the fecal-oral route, whereby eggs shed in the feces of a person with an active tapeworm infection are ingested by another person and then hatch into larvae that can penetrate the intestinal wall and reach a variety of tissues where they form cysts. This is a dead-end in the life cycle of the tapeworm. In fact, the intended host for the egg of the tapeworm is pigs; just like in humans, ingestion of the egg by pigs eventually leads to the development of cysticerci in a variety of tissues, including the musculature of the pig. When the musculature is consumed by a human in the form of undercooked infected pork, the cysticerci can develop into a tapeworm that infects the human and completes the life cycle.

Neurocysticercosis is often indolent, with lesions found incidentally when brain imaging is performed for other reasons. This is likely the case for this patient, whose clinical presentation is most consistent with a gastroenteritis with volume depletion. In other cases of neurocysticercosis, patients may present with symptoms several decades after leaving the endemic area. Typical symptoms include seizures and headaches with hydrocephalus related to obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow by cysticerci. There are four main pathological stages of neurocysticercosis: vesicular, colloidal, granular nodular, and calcified. The final, calcified, stage is inactive and can remain asymptomatic.

All patients with suspected neurocysticercosis should receive brain imaging with both a CT of the head and an MRI of the brain (ideally with contrast) to further confirm the diagnosis, to localize and quantify the lesions (cysts can be parenchymal, intraventricular, meningeal, subarachnoid, or subependymal), and to assess whether the parasite is still viable. The most common finding is a calcified cyst, which represents the remains of the parasite after it has died. Antiparasitic treatment is not typically indicated in patients with only calcified cysts. It should be noted that serologic testing, using an enzyme-linked immunotransfer blot, is also available and could be ordered for this patient, but it is complementary to brain imaging, not a substitute for it.

Key learning point: Patients with suspected neurocysticercosis should be evaluated with both CT of the head and MRI of the brain with contrast.

C) INCORRECT:

Stool examination for ova and parasites would be an appropriate test for tapeworm infestation. However, in cysticercosis, the parasite is located in other tissues, such as the brain, and thus infestation cannot be diagnosed with stool studies.

D) INCORRECT:

MR spectroscopy is used to study metabolic changes and tissue composition, most frequently in brain tumors. Although this patient’s presentation is suggestive of an intracranial mass or increased intracranial pressure — both of which could be seen in the setting of a tumor — MRI with contrast would be the most appropriate test to rule out the presence of a tumor and would therefore be indicated before considering MR spectroscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

CT perfusion studies are used in acute stroke cases, to assess infarct core versus ischemic penumbra. The subacute course in this patient, as well as the lack of focal neurologic findings on examination, argue against acute stroke in this case.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension presents for evaluation of cough. He was at his baseline state of health until one week ago when he developed low-grade fevers, fatigue, dyspnea, and dry cough. Two weeks ago, he returned from a month-long trip to Nicaragua where he was participating in a language-immersion program. While traveling, he ate locally prepared food, including street food, and drank bottled water; he had no ill contacts. His current medications are hydroxychloroquine and lisinopril. He has no drug allergies.
On examination, his temperature is 38.1°C, his blood pressure is 140/82 mm Hg, his heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. He appears fatigued. He has diffuse expiratory wheezes bilaterally on auscultation of the lungs. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
8500
4500–11,000


Neutrophils (%)
52
40–70


Band forms (%)
0
0–10


Lymphocytes (%)
23
22–44


Eosinophils (%)
20
0–8


Basophils (%)
5
0–3


Hemoglobin (g/dl)
14
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
260,000
150,000–350,000


Electrolyte levels and liver function test results are unremarkable.
A chest radiograph shows patchy consolidation in both lung fields.
The patient is prescribed a 5-day course of prednisone and an albuterol inhaler. One month later, he reports that he feels back to his baseline, and a repeat chest radiograph and leukocyte differential are normal.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient at this time?

choices.text: Spirometry, followed by methacholine challenge if negative
Stool testing for ova and parasites

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:
